content:
er 11, 2015
												F.E.A.R 3 is the last game in the F.E.A.R  series thus far, releasing in mid 2011 on PC, Xbox360 and PS3 being developed by Day 1 Studios, the same guys which developed the first F.E.A.R on PS3 and Xbox360. The bulk of the gameplay is the same as the previous titles with a few minor changes.  The main one being a change to how the cover system work. In the previous games you used to be able to tilt your character’s head around corners in order to shoot, F.E.A.R 3 adds a peeking system, where you can hug up against any sort of cover and drop your headup and down whilst also moving side to side in order to shoot from cover. This for me felt a lot easier to handle than the previous version and is a really nice change.  The rest of the game play is very much the same, I was a little bit let down by the gun mechanics however, I praised the first game heavily due to how the gun play feels so fluid and responsive, sadly in 3 I had a lot of trouble aiming whilst looking down the sight and spent the majority of the time shooting from the hip. This was mainly because the hit detection on the bullets is quite a bit off, you can sometimes get a direct hit on an enemies head and nothing happens.  There is only one new weapon to be introduced in the game too, a freezing gun which you obtain by overcoming one of the many fights with the same boss throughout the single player campaign mode. Graphically, F.E.A.R 3 looks OK. It is 4 years old at this point and you can tell it is part of the last generation of gaming, but it still holds it’s own compared to games released around that time. The texture quality is just bog standard OK again, where the F.E.A.R series does well, is the animation of the characters, they all have a very good ragdoll effect to them, meaning death animations are all on point and can result in some unique positions. F.E.A.R 3 isn’t hard when playing on the medium settings; FPS vetrans need to bump it up to hard mode for it to be even slightly challenging; I don’t think I died more than two times throughout the whole game which is something to be said given the amount of bosses you have to fight.  Some levels are actually made significantly easier since they give you a mech suit to use which whilst it is absolutely satisfying to blow up enemies at point blank range with missiles, it does make the level seem somewhat pointless as there is no challenge and just feels more like a time block than anything else. Unlike the previous games; the levels in F.E.A.R 3 are very linear and leave very little for the player to explore and find secrets/collectables. There is one collectable on each level which is randomly placed every time you play, but there isn’t extra bits of lore/plot to be found from hacking computers, or finding documents;  something which I did miss as the story in this game is actually somewhat interesting compared to the last games. A single play through this game took me just under four hours; where you will get the majority of your replay ability from F.E.A.R 3 is the co-op mode and challenge system. This is the first F.E.A.R game to have any sort of co-op mode in and it does it very well. The multiplayer missions feel very much like Killing Floor, so if you enjoyed that, you will get some enjoyment out of the F.E.A.R 3 multiplayer too. I only had one technical issue whilst playing, and that was when playing with more than on screen, your mouse will sometimes exit the screen you are playing on and when you click to shoot, you’ll minimize to your desktop as it has roamed onto another screen – this became a real annoyance on the latter levels when you have very little time to react to things. I was unable to find a fix for this online so be warned! To sum up, F.E.A.R 3 is definitely not as good as the previous two games, but it does offer something a bit different. The price on Steam of £12,99 is a bit steep given the shortness of the single player, but you can pick up the entire F.E.A.R collection from Bundle Stars for a mere £3.26 - https://www.bundlestars.com/en/bundle/fear-bundle  meaning you can’t really go wrong with picking the title up there.  Going off that, I am only going to recommend F.E.A.R 3 when it is on sale.  Tom's Score Card1) Stay away2) Not Recommended3) Only recommended when on sale4) Recommended5) Highly recommended6) This is a must playIf you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up. You can also find more reviews over at http://www.completingthebackloggroup.com/Please also check out Completing the Backlog's Curator page here - follow for regular updates on reviews for other games!

content:
15, 2014
												FEAR 3 represents what is wrong with many 'modernization' processes of games. It takes everything that people liked about the first few games in the series and just replaces or modifies them to work with current trends, such as in this case regenerating health, co-op, perks... However, I would also argue FEAR 3 is not a bad game. If you're looking for a game akin to FEAR 1 or 2, this unfortunately is not it. It also is pretty lacking in the horror department. It's not scary, or even really atmospheric, though it attempts to be. What it is though, is a pretty fun multiplayer experience.The story will probably ♥♥♥♥-off long-time fans. Without going too deep into spoilers, the story basically focuses mostly on Fettel, the antagonist from the first game. The story's already kind of in a mess from the get-go, as we have things from psychic powers, clones, the fact our two main characters are the sons of the series main antagonist Alma, and just other plot elements that just scream they're so bad. But it's not badly written to be fair, and if you kind of turn off your brain it's kind of stupid entertainment. But you really shouldn't be playing this game for the story.The campaign should last for about 5-7 hours, with some highs and lows, but that in no way compares to the previous two games. The co-op helps make it a bit more fun, for better or worse. The two brothers play completely differently though, with Pointman basically being your typical action hero with the guns and the slide-kicks, and Fettel being actually surprisingly rather fresh, being a psychic man who can levitate enemies, possess them, shoot energy blasts, and more. Honestly, both are pretty fun, but I have to hand it to Fettel as for a game with very little inspiration behind it, his gameplay is actually rather original for this sort of game and fun.But it's not the campaign you should be buying FEAR 3 for, as weird as that might sound. I find most people never delve into the multiplayer modes in this game. And it's sensible, as the campaign is disappointing and usually multiplayer modes are tagged on without much thought or effort, so it's probably nothing special, right?Well, that's wrong, as it turns out the multiplayer modes in this game are actually the best part of the game.I can't even count how many friends who got FEAR 3 that ended up loving the multiplayer modes and hating the campaign. Let me explain; The campaign lacks tension, and often is a bit repetitive, on-top of the fact it just feels rather uninspired most of the time, its horror elements fail, and its action sequences aren't particularly great. But something FEAR 3 does surprisingly well is understand the fun elements of multiplayer shooters. Hell, some of the multiplayer modes are even far more tense and more horror-like than anything in the campaign.Multiplayer is split into four modes, and all four are pretty fun for up to four-players either locally or online. Each mode has different maps. One mode has you all as ghost phantoms who possess bodies and try to kill other enemies and your friends to collect souls, most souls at the end of a wave wins the round, and at the end of all waves, person with the most rounds won wins. Another mode has you in an open arena with multiple areas to station yourself in as you and friends fight hordes of enemies that come in waves, boarding up windows and between waves going out to collect supplies. It's a sort of rip-off of Zombie mode from CoD, but it has some interesting twists, such as Alma, who you should not look at as she'll cause randomized effects against you, ranging from just downing you to making you see your friends as enemies, making the screen go black, or teleporting you to another random point on the map. Or a fog, that gets thicker and thicker as the waves go on, and an unseen red-light monster lurks in the deeper parts of the fog... And in yet another mode, you and up to three friends run away from a giant wall of death. Really challenging, frantic, tense, panic-worthy, but a lot of fun as a lot of enemies get tossed your way and you only get small breathers to quickly recollect supplies before the wall is out it again. A race from death and survival that is both primal but also strategic and fun.The game also looks pretty good, and the PC port is well-done. Music works, but nothing outside of the credits song sticks as being particularly memorable.FEAR 3 is against most everything the FEAR series stands for, but if you can look over that and a disappointing campaign, I guarantee you there's some multiplayer fun here that may be worth experiencing.

content:
11
												I have to agree with some of the other reviews I've read here since playing the game. The FEAR series started off as a game that was truly it's own genre; paranormal FPS. It stood proudly amongst it's predecessors like DOOM and Castle Wolfenstien.  The scare element was in the fact that you had all the firepower in the world, but it amounted to nothing to what was truly terrfying; a psychic ghost that is Alma, who seems hellbent on either scaring you to death, or burning you, whichever comes first. The first game really playing into lighting, textures and sound; right at the cusp of when the gaming world was really experimenting and playing with those elements. The enviroment was great, the gameplay was pretty smooth for its time. The combat was fun (slow-mo done right), the story was intriguing with just the right touch of spooky mystery, and the scare moments were downright terrifying. Had more than a few moments where I had to save and quit simply because my overly beating heart couldn't take anymore. Overall a very solid horror game that was quite a few years ahead of it's time. 9/10FEAR 2 brought in more of a balance between the combat and the scare moments. The combat was much much smoother compared to FEAR, and the graphics were amazing compared to other games of it's time. You still played a silent protaginist, which was odd considering that you don't officially play as Pointman, but overall the story was very tight and the scare moments were still pretty scary and fairly unpredictable. Overall an improvement in some subtle ways, but there were a few moments where it seemed a little TOO combat heavy. A for effort though, and I have to say I enjoyed playing it across the board. 7/10And then FEAR 3...changed developers, which can be either really good or really bad for a game mid/end series, and right during the COD craze being at it's peak. And by God did it show. Restricted to 2 weapons, majority of the weapons vanilla and mediocre. Over half the special weapons gone, and the really fun ones (Nail gun and laser gun I'm looking at you two) were only given sparcely during the end and really had next to no screen time. The scare moments were also next to non-existent, despite a few gems of those moments being hidden here and there, and the combat was so heavy and pointless it felt like I was playing more of a crappy, cheap horror rendition of a Call of Duty game than a horror FPS. And since a lot of the expansions from the first two games was rendered non-canon, the story had a ton of plot holes and the ending was just crap with it being so open ended. I was vastly disappointed with how a wonderful game series that I had grown to love had crashed and burned so horribly. If you're looking to simply finish the story, if you can even call it that it's so bad, from the previous games that is virtually the only semi-good reason to buy this game. Otherwise, I wouldn't recommend it at all. 2-3/10

content:
er 1, 2014
												Well, well, well. Another shooter has fallen to the subscriptions of substandard Call-of-Duty-esque gaming.F.E.A.R. 3 is a game in which you (assuming you play as Point Man, the long-time protagonist of the series.) and your dead, cannibal brother, whom you killed, team up to... Uhmmm. Do something? It involves Alma's baby. That's all that's really made apparent.Firstly, the "dramatic story-line" they boast about on the store page has little relation to the actual game. The story-line was little more than a rail for you to follow from shooty-segment to shooty-segment. In fact, since Point Man is completely mute, they never really elaborate on why exactly he wants Alma's baby. Maybe it's to shoot it? But that contradicts the ending... I dunno.Secondly, the game is named FEAR. Shouldn't actual fear be it's main and central focus? Well, it's not. In fact, the FEAR franchise has gotten less and less scary as time's gone on. Sure, there'll be the creepy black figure running across a gate every once in a while, but it all falls flat when you perform a psychic link on a random corpse for "Rank Points" and it gets plastered all over your screen in the middle of the supposed horror that you "HAVE RANKED UP TO LEVEL __"Lastly, however, the co-op is fun. Not exactly difficult, even in the hardest difficulty, a friend of mine was able to pick the game up and immediately demolish everything. But nonetheless, it was fun. However, it continues to take away from the percieved horror of the game. No matter what game it is, cooperative horror doesn't work. When you have a friend singing "Fireball" on the mic, any horror in the scene tends to be lost.So, if you played the original F.E.A.R. and are looking for a second dose of the thrilling horror that was in the first game, go buy the original Dead Space. If you're looking for a great story plot with lots of depth and heart-wrenching moments, then go buy The Walking Dead Seasons 1 & 2. If you're looking for a mediocre cooperative experience to share with your friends for about 5 hours of game-time, however, then you've come to the right place.TL;DR: Not scary, not deep in story, not good single player, not difficult, but a nice little 5 hour time-sink for you and a friend.I do not recommend this game,»ZCC« Zombie Chicken

content:
er 27, 2013
												The first F.E.A.R. was an outstanding masterpiece. The two following expansion packs were so so.F.E.A.R. 2 was great in my opinion. The game had a crappy story although the pacing of the game was good, it also featured a smart AI, it had amazing visuals (fire effect, smoke, explosion, close combat, firefights, etc), some great scares and a convincing atmosphere, etc.F.E.A.R 3 features an even smarter AI. The enemy soldiers are quick to take cover, switch positions, retreat, suppress you, throw grenades, flank you and charge you when they can. There's also plenty of enemy chatter that you can hear which allows you to anticipate some of your enemies' movements. They will also call you out if you are hiding for too long.Needless to say, the AI as advanced as it is in Killzone 2,3 which features the smartest FPS AI to date. In fact, the AI is sometimes so smart, it becomes punishing. Plus there's no blind fire option, you make peek out of your cover and unleash small burst but you will almost certainly get return fire. Your screen WILL stay red for an extended period of time after being shot at. You may also chose to stay in cover until the red screen goes away, but sometimes you can get approached by a guy with a shotgun who will blow you away.Your flashlight will also expose you to your enemies just like in the first game. However, I tested this further and found out that the enemies will react to your flashlight even IF they do not face you, meaning they react to your flashlight being turned on, they don't react to the flashlight necessarily because the AI field of vision picks it up.The cover system is outstanding and I can only wish that most if not all FPS featured this kind of cover system. The Killzone franchise invented this realistic cover system first though.When you take cover, you do not get the chance to view yourself in the third person perspective nor will you be able to magically see everything that is going on around you. This time, the only way for you to view your surroundings is to peek from a cover. It is too bad there's no leaning option, but you can lean easily when in cover.The bullet time is back and it works the same way it did in F.E.A.R 2, although it drains slightly faster, at first at least.Oh and also, Paxton Fettel is back! Damn did I miss his voice. "They all deserve to die..." Although, if you want to play single player, you can only play as Point Man. Your co-op buddy therefore can play as Fettel. This time around, Alma won't shred your enemies as often. You'll have to rely on Fettel more to do the job. Although you yourself have some psychotelepathic skills. Fettel's abilities are slightly overpowered but he makes for an awesome anti-hero.However, F.E.A.R has always been a franchise about the single-player experience. The co-op campaign might be slightly unfounded here. Fettel's occasional remarks do not ruin the immersion of the game, but they do ruin the time when you immerse yourself enough to believe that you are the only one fighting the enemy - all by yourself. He is always there somehow, watching your every step, so you never really feel alone. Ultimately, the co-op is a great add-on, I'm just not sure if the F.E.A.R. franchise really needed it. There are some games out there that scream co-op but don't have any, such as Clive Barker's Jericho for instance.There's also a horde mode, reminiscent of the Call of Duty Zombie mode. You still build barricades and get better weapons but this time you are fighting the smart AI that is assaulting your position instead of shooting brain dead zombies.In general, the game play is extremely rewarding. The guns feel real, although shotgun looks quite idiotic.The firefights are realistic enough: the recoil, the smoking barrel,the destructible environments, the matrix-looking like bullet movement in slow mo, the human-like AI - it's all there. You can also slide over cover just like in Brink.In general, the controls are pretty fluid except for when you push the button to take cover and then if you need to desperately displace, you will need to push the button again to exit cover and sometimes that will get you killed, unless you keep pushing "S" but forget about exiting cover any other way but by pressing the cover button. Switching cover is also very fluid - something that Killzone did not introduce.Another huge positive note is that you can actually see your legs! how awesome is that? You don't get to see that too often. However, you do not cast a shadow all the time, just in some places. Also, one of the most satisfying things in F.E.A.R. is throwing a grenade at a couple of guys, shooting a couple of guys in slo-mo and finally kicking the last standing guy in the face therefore destroying the entire squad in seconds.The graphics are satisfying to say the least, there's also Directx11 (IGN's gripe about the supposedly outdated graphics while reviewing the game on PS3 is therefore unwarranted; the AI issue is also redundant because the AI is insanely smart). The story is enough to keep you playing although the cheap Alma scare tactics can give you slight jumps even though some of them are cliche and predictable. The atmosphere is solid, there are some major set pieces.On the negative side, those mech robots are back and man do I hate those stages. I prefer a great tactical FPS as opposed to silly arcade mech warrior shoot-ups. I'm disappointed they brought these mechs stages over from F.E.A.R. 2. because these frustrating levels are unnecessary.The game gives you plenty of opportunity to sneak on enemies and take out one or two before others react, but the game does not give you the opportunity to silently kill the two and have the ability to shoot the rest in a quick fashion.Also, the melee kills should be worked out. It feels sluggish and consolish because the melee kills are auto aimed for you. Sometimes you get to kill your enemies instantly with a knife if the knife slices their head. Sometimes, you have to slash them several times for them to die, not only that, they often have the balls to fight back as you keep slashing their face.Ultimately there's not that many negatives, as far as the solid gameplay is concerned anyway, F.E.A.R. 3 is a solid shooter.

27, 2016
												Fear 3 is the weakest link of the Fear series and it doesn't feel like a true FEAR game. It changes so many things that didn't need any changes and introduced some new things to the franchise that are not compatible with a horror shooter. But the worst thing about this game is that it is a console port with console game mechanics.+ Graphics are nice+ Sound is good+ Some characters of the franchise are in the game+ Co-op campaign- Weapon variety is reduced. Also, after every mission you lose your weapons again, which isn't that immersive.- The plotline is a mess.- Linear and small console maps. Even objects that are not high can't always be jumped over.. - Health regeneration was introduced. This doesn't fit into a horror game.- This game is such a horror game that you can earn skills and even pick up Alma dolls. :P- The final chapter is anti-climaticFear 3 is an average fps, but a bad Fear game. I can't recommend buying this game except if you are a die-hard FEAR fan and want to play this game despite its faults.Replay value: Only with a friend or if you want to play as FettelRating: 6.5/10Recommendation: No for a Fear game, neutral for a fps

content:
ry 4, 2014
 If you like shooters it's okay. If you like F.E.A.R. it's bad. This game should have never been called fear. I say this not just for the spurious representation of the classic fear games, but for the fact the game is not scary. The original fear is in my option a revolutionary game, the level of detail and thought put into it was tremendous. This game however has little to none to connect this to the original fear.   The Replicants are gone. The invisible assassins are gone. This does not seem to be a fear game, and that is a good way to put it as this game seems more like another. Call of duty clone is not a term that should be used likely but the similarities are far too obvious, nearly all of the original mechanics of fear(health/armor, specialized weapons) have been torn out to put in call of duty mechanics(health regeneration, riot shield, flash grenades.).The first level says it all for me. I start crawling through the jail not sure what going to happen when I realized. It's too bright. The first “scare” was little more than an special effect and Alma saying hello. Next a power failure, finally some scary scenes. However before one jump scare the lights come back on. Finally, I as the middle of a firefight when I see an enemy above me on a catwalk. My thoughts went as follows. “Crud, im going to have to walk around to get at him.. wait, this a fear game, there quality games, I should be able to shoot through the floor!” this is when I realized this is no fear game.   And it really isn’t a fear game. Like the other fear games, it was not made on the LithTech engine. This engine gave fear so much more than other games. I already notice several missing refinements. The levels where sloppy. In the first you knew what way to go. It gave you plenty of lighting hints movements and other cues to push you in the right direction. I got lost many times in this one.  Lastly the story, to be honest, If you did not play Fear 2 you would not care about 70% of this story. Truthfully If point man where to just walk away the same ending would have happened.  There are many issues with the story that I could argue but I think the main issue I had was Alma. All the way through the fear games Alma has been set as a boogeyman. And even though a new creep one was created for this she is still this silent super being, beging in the shadows in the first game was okay. This was the story of the story, but now that we have reached the end her character barely develops from being a bump in the night.

content:
1, 2014
												Remember F.E.A.R. when it first came out and you wanted to play it even though your system couldn't even handle it?  Perhaps, that was not the case for you, but it was for me.  Eventually, I was able to run it with decent hardware and I never looked back.F.E.A.R. stepped into the seen in slow-mo and then it took the first-person shooter genre by storm, tailored to shooter and survival-horror fans.  F.E.A.R. 3, while the weaker follow-up to the F.E.A.R. series still holds up as an atmospheric game with solid gunplay and an interestingly shocking ending like its predecessor.  Some may complain that the formula is becoming boring and stale, but it is still a perfectly decent addition to the franchise.As a fan of the Dead Space series, I found F.E.A.R. 3 to have a commanding presence when it comes to atmosphere.  I would argue that F.E.A.R. 3 nails the atmosphere and overall eerie-filled environments better than Dead Space 3. The attentional to detail is more adequate in some areas than others, but it has enough going in that department to earn a ribbon.  The gunplay is rock-solid, which makes gameplay worthwhile.  Along with the cover system that lets you peek while in cover, quickly lean to the opposite side and aim, it nails the cover-system just right.  For those that are looking for a more conventional F.E.A.R. 3 tactic and approach to gameplay, it is still all there and nothing much has changed if you want to use slow-mo and the run-and-gun variety.  Even on the easiest difficulty, F.E.A.R. 3 can present some difficulty spikes.  A franchise that basically expects a player to run-and-gun using the slow-mo function, you could be taken down quickly on normal difficulty.  It asks you to be tactical while using slow-mo.  It is slightly different from F.E.A.R. 1 in that you are not only running into singular rooms, using slow-mo, and unloading.  There are plenty of cover usage so you will need to run from one cover to another while using slow-mo.  Think of it as a Chinese action film with lots of gun-fighting.  It can be quite satisifying at times, but the variation comes in with using cover to get to where you need to go without dying outright.  I hear it is a common complaint among the series' fans, but I did not find a major issue with it.F.E.A.R. 3 is far from great and it is worth noting that it is not spectacular as the original F.E.A.R.  Either way, it manages to be a perfectly decent addition to the series without presenting any major quams.  It is successful at being a solid first-person shooter with the well-known F.E.A.R. elements.  While I cannot comment on the co-operative play because I have no experience in it, F.E.A.R. 3 offers enough there to warrant a purchase on a decent sale.  I paid $5 for it and I thought that it was worth it.  I cannot say for sure if it would have been worth $10 though.  It's a rock-solid game to the series.  Just do not expect another F.E.A.R. 1 and you will enjoy it for what it offers.  Game on,ElannRating: 7 out of 10

number of helpful: 35 of 43 people (81%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2014
												The history of F.E.A.R's development has swapped hands through practically every expansion and installment and which each one, a new take on the franchise was created. Most, if nearly all, fans of the series consider the first F.E.A.R to be the 'best' due to its thick, tense atmosphere and and engaging combat and I agree to a point. F.E.A.R 1 still out plays most shooters and horror games today! So with that legacy and high standard already set from the get go, it'd cetainly be a challenge to meet it again, especially in the hands of a different developer! As a result, many people tend to look down on F.E.A.R 3 as being a 'generic' CoD clone and this couldn't be more of a lie!F.E.A.R 3 is certainly different to its predecessor in terms of pace, atmosphere and horror. It's not what I'd call a horror game and that may be a turn off for most. But what it lacks in creepy it certainly MORE than makes up for in fun and replayability! The standard of combat is very much maintained despite the (shock horror) regenerating health and cover systems. The guns have a very engaging feel to them, enemies being gibbed and pinned to the wall or heads popping to the lined up headshot let you know you're in a F.E.A.R game! Regenerating health seems more fitting to the title as the levels are not as big and large scale combat happens a lot more frequently, not giving you time to look for those hidden health boosts in previous games. Cover system can be taken or left, it's simply another option of play style which leads to another staple feature of F.E.A.R 3. Pointman? Fettel? or both? You can now play as the big bad lil' brother in F.E.A.R, who comes with his own unique playstyle of possessing enemies and harassing them with supernatural powers. This can lead to great gameplay choices like choosing who to possess based on position, type of enemy or weapon they're carrying. Pointman's slow mo reflexes and neo martial arts return also adding more choices to how you take out your enemies. While either character is a blast to play with, the real fun and where the game truly shines comes when both monsters are on the field together in the form of co-op. The whole game can be played together where the two brothers tackle the campaign in a ironically funny way. Pointman can slow down time to help Fettel with his possessions or Fettel can quickly take out a strong enemy harassing pointman by either suspending him in midway for Pointman to finish or for Fettel to possess! There's a rewarding and competitive points system in each playthrough to decide who ultimately is the favourite son! Some actions can be performed where you greedily obtain all the points of a situation or share them with your brother depending on the bond with your 'brother' (after all this a game about the strength of 'family' :P) Seeing Alma subtely appear through out levels is a nice nod to her freaky apperances in previous F.E.A.R games and it was always a cool thing to find! Some level designs and moments can lead to an eerie feeling, but nothing you'd expect from 1, still it's nice to have it there, it doesn't feel like some tacked on thing to a shooter. Multiplayer is surprisingly engaging, with fun unique game modes like 'JUST F**KING RUN' where you and your team are being chased by a fog of screaming death and your goal is to just keep running towards the goal while taking out enemy obstacles in your path! Though you can't get held up for too long and the fog is ever approaching! Contractions revolves around your team mates stock piling crates found in the map that provide you with weapons and ammo. You repair barricades to doors and windows and together you must hold out against waves of ever strengthening opponents! But be careful! As Alma stalks the rooms and streets and if she catches you staring at her, you're in for a terrible time...All in all I was so pleasantly surprised to know that the F,E,A,R legacy (despite the popular cries) was kept in tact whie Day One Studios added their own interpretation to the series and it worked! F.E.A.R 3 is a more than solid shooter that, for me, is still fun and replayable after already 6 playthroughs. The game is short enough for one playthrough with a buddy, take a lll 10 minute break then go straight back, swapping roles and doing it again which is exactly what me and my girlfriend did! It keeps the campaign lean and eventful, nothing tacked on to try and trick you that your getting you money's worth simply because it was so and so many hours long. The game is fun by itself but ultimately, F.E.A.R 3 is best played with a 'brother'. Whether your experience will be about brotherly love or sibling rivalry will depend on you!

content:
ber 6, 2016
												First problem is that they changed developers, Monolith did not create this game because Day 1 Studios did. So if you are wondering why it doesn't feel like a F.E.A.R. game then that might have something to do with it. Second problem is that the atmosphere did not have the same feeling at all compared to the first and second F.E.A.R. titles. It's as if they changed it from a vengeful spirit sort of thing to people being possessed by demons.Third problem is why is the mysterious "point man" and Fettel being haunted by the spirit of their father? I didn't get the impression from the first game that Harlan would have had such an impact on them out of nowhere. The gameplay was alright for a shooter but seemed horrible for a FEAR title. The cover mechanic was cool but the weapons are practically garbage on what they were like in the previous two titles. They removed the HP bar and the Armor bar, they took the ridiculous Battlefield & Call of Duty route with the HP. HP is much lower than it used to be and it regenerates itself, not a good thing to change in my opinion. Armacam looks different again. Overall it is fun to play if you didn't care for the main games or if you can overlook the fact they changed developers. If you really enjoyed FEAR for what it was for the first and second installments then you might be disappointed. I am certainly upset that they went from Monolith to Day 1 Studios.

number of helpful: 43 of 61 people (70%) found this review helpful5 people found this review funny
content:
, 2015
												I don't see why all the hatred for this game. Sure, it seems like a generic shooter, sure, it's not as good as the past games, sure, it's not scary at all (Hell, not even the "scary" parts were remotely close to being scary to me), but still, I enjoyed this game.It's pretty much mindless, dumb fun, not supposed to be taken seriously (Which I know that past games were supposed to be like that), and co-op isn't that bad, to be fair. Of course, playing this game on Co-op makes this game anything BUT scary. Mostly because you can't split up. Co-op horror games are creepy when you are forced to split up. This game doesn't make you do that, hell, you can't even move far away from your partner because (If you are playing as Fettel) you will be immediatly teleported to your nearest Pointman. Combat can get a bit monotonous at times, fight soldiers here, destroy mechs over there, slay a few anarchy zombies, and use a giant robot yourself! With an exploit, it seems. If you are about to die and you leave the mech and get back inside as quickly as you can, your health will be fully restored. That made the bridge level MUCH easier. I dunno if mechs count, I dunno if the phase guys in giant suits count, hell, I dunno if the power generator you gotta shot count as bosses. For me, there was only one boss, the final boss. Which....Can be killed in a couple of minutes, which in turn is a huge dissapointment. BUT IT DOESN'T MATTER, DANZIG AT THE END CREDITS! Of course, the game is pretty damn short, I finished it in less than 4 hours, which is kind of a dissapointment. That's my only complaint about this game. If you are a die hard fan of the series, I wouldn't really recommend this. If you are just a fan of the series, sure, go ahead. If you are a lover of mindless shooters that can be plain and perhaps a bit repetitive at times, it's a must buy!

number of helpful: 59 of 90 people (66%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
er 11, 2014
												F.E.A.R. 3 is an average, and unremarkable, horror first person shooter.  If you have ever played a fps then you'll be familiar will everything that F.E.A.R. 3 has to offer, if you have never played a fps before... well that kind of odd and remarkable, and you probably shouldn't have your first fps experience with F.E.A.R. 3. This isn't to suggest that F.E.A.R. 3 is a bad game, but more to the fact that the game lacks polish. It has some nice things going for it, the campaign gameplay varies enough to stay fresh, there is co-op (which I didn't get to experience since none of my friends have this game), and the two playable characters feel slightly different from each other. However, the game has significant things going against it. For starters, it isn't scary, which is a problem, considering that it is a horror fps. Second, the campaign itself drags on for way too long and often feels like it is stretching things out, just to fully use an environment (a la, if we spent months making a haunted department store, then the player is going to see every freaking room in it). And lastly, the game's story is very narrow and straight to the point, so if you haven't played the previous games in the series, you'll not going to understand everything that is going on, and even if you did, you're still not going to understand everything.If you play this game under ideal conditions (co-op with a good friend that scares easily) then I would image that this game would be great, however, that isn't going to happen for the vast majority of people, so this game is not worth it.

content:
ry 2, 2014
												As a major fan of the F.E.A.R. Franchise and playing all the games, it hurts me to say that this game is likely the worst of the entire franchise. WB games made a LOT of bad choices with this one. The thing that made F.E.A.R. and its expansion packs scary was sometimes, you don't know if what you are experiencing is a hallucination or the real thing until the end. "Was that person who walked down that corridor real?" You would ask yourself, you would then go down that hallway to help that person to just find a bloodfilled deadend with a healthpack, you would then turn around to see that person you saw stand right in front of you, horribly mutilated before fading into ashes.F.E.A.R. 2 Was scary but not in the same way as the first, almost everything paranormal or scary you saw was real, not a hallucination which kind of kills the mood. You can tell F.E.A.R. 2 was more focused on combat and some levels were even more Linear than F.E.A.R. F.E.A.R. at least let you explore for health boosters or reflex boosters, or even different guns. F.E.A.R. 2 however only rewarded you with reflex boosters or intel laying out in the open.This release, F.E.A.R. 3 had a lot of incoming hype but was ultimately, WB games' futile attempt to close the F.E.A.R. story. It seems that this one was focused entirely on combat though there is not a lot of variation to the enemies. The Co-op option doesnt make my opineon of the game better either, just a way for WB to continue jumping the shark. It may not even as well be CALLED Co-op as it seems to be a competitive shooter to see who can kill more bad guys, who can do more of their special maneuvers and who can ♥♥♥♥ eachother over more by stealing a psychic link behind your partner's back. This isnt the game for you if you want a shooter with occasional scares like the last 2 F.E.A.R.s, ultimately, major F.E.A.R. fans will be disappointed. If you wish to close the F.E.A.R story and dont give a crap about scares, go right ahead. On the other hand, if you want an experience that was in years of development and delivers a ton of scares, this one you can definently skip.

content:
ry 1
												So, so many things wrong with this game, but in short: they forgot to think while designing it, and threw out so many good, already working ideas through the windows.We got back Point Man, the mute hero from the first game, but in F3AR we have multiple awkward third-person cutscenes where people talk to him, and he just stares angrily like a neanderthal.The combat features "evolutionary slow-mo modes" that's apparently still revolutionary, 6 years, 2 games and 3 expansions later. Also the combat is strictly cover-based shooter with iron sights, auto-healing,  bad granade-throwing physics and bad AI, ocassionally a mech section. Also it has about 4 different types of enemy if we don't count the different weapons on them.*edit: and a sneak peek into AI: I crossed a corridor and got hidden behind the corner, and the enemy started having radio chatter about how did I vanished, impossible, and started to repeatedly look after me in a 2m*2m room without them realizing that I can not be there.The gameplay has close to no horror elements, just sh*tloads of gore because apparently blood paintings = horror. The game ignored the second game's story and Fettel is still just a spirit, despite him having a new body (so a gimmicky coop can work), and changed the storyline so Alma, who was multiple times stated went straight-out crazy (and murderous) around 6 YO, was actually a misunderstood child who never wanted to hurt anyone but "her demons" were drawing out the evil in her.  The whole game just... changed from dark and threatening and manipulative into teenage horror movie props and save the little girl themes... and also don't forget the levelup and xp system that makes so many xp popups on the screen during playing that it's severely distracting.Add the abysmal looking graphics to this - it looks like someone smeared vaseline over the screen, everything is blurry that's more than 4 metres far... I can't believe that Fear 1 and 2 looks so, so much better than this game.The only positive thing I could point out that's the coop campaign because it's really rare that it's present in games, but uninspired cookie-cutter covershooter with slapped on FEAR story and bad graphics doesn't make me want to relive the campaign ever again. It was well enough once.

												Note: This game been tried out and reviewed in Steam offline mode or on Consoles.The first F.E.A.R. was an outstanding masterpiece. The two following expansion packs were so so.F.E.A.R 3 features an even smarter AI. The enemy soldiers are quick to take cover, switch positions, retreat, suppress you, throw grenades, flank you and charge you when they can. There's also plenty of enemy chatter that you can hear which allows you to anticipate some of your enemies' movements. They will also call you out if you are hiding for too long.There's also a horde mode, reminiscent of the Call of Duty Zombie mode. You still build barricades and get better weapons but this time you are fighting the smart AI that is assaulting your position instead of shooting brain dead zombies.Ultimately there are not that many negatives, as far as the solid gameplay is concerned.Overall: F.E.A.R. 3 is a solid shooter.

												What an atrocity...FEAR 1 and 2 were absolutely fantastic games that were unrivaled in the fusion of Horror and FPS, and still are, to this day. Eventually FEAR 3 came along to complete the trilogy. FEAR 1 had atmosphere, difficulty, great story and great gameplay. FEAR 2 had more of the same, but with a more streamlined approach to the story, but it didn't have as many open ended levels.FEAR 3 ditched the horror, the good writing and ended up adding COOP to follow the COOP craze. The level design is horribly linear, with no options of going in a different way. Do yourselves a favor and stay away from this atrocity. number of helpful: 10 of 10 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
er 27, 2013
												This is a mixed bag, leaned more towards the negative side due to history. I recommend this game if you want a quick time killer with a friend or more, as this is a good generic shooter. As a F.E.A.R. game, it is nothing but disappointment all around, and it's not just because of the lack of scares like a lot of people say, it involves many other things. Single PlayerThe way the story is told is underwhelming, there is no more mystery and atmosphere, hardly any suspense, or anything to look out for in order to aid your knowledge on what is going on. They blatantly killed off almost every single character from the previous games, without any logic or explanation; they were either forgotten, or cut off from the story. Makes me surprised they even brought Jin Sun-Kwon back, but not characters like Holiday, Betters, Aristide, among many others. The gameplay is functional, don't get me wrong, but like almost everything in this, it no longer feels like F.E.A.R., the only essence left there is the slow-motion, certain melee attacks, and very few weapons.I'd say it's like Call of Duty with a cover system no one cares about. The amazing soundtrack the series contained simply disappeared here, and was replaced by a lackluster and utterly forgettable one. The only redeeming quality of a F.E.A.R. game this has in my opinion, is Paxton Fettel himself, who while looks different and has abilities that feel uninspired and limited, retained not only his voice actor, but also his character and cold behavior. Another complaint is that the game is extremely short, you can finish it in under 4 hours.MultiplayerThe multiplayer is nothing like the previous' games. It tends to be co-op focused, even though 2 of the 4 game modes are competitive (Soul King and Soul Survivor). Contractions' core mechanics remind me of Call of Duty's Zombies mode, which while not necessarily bad, lacks originality. Good game mode, regardless. In ♥♥♥♥ing Run the players have to push through waves of enemies while running from Alma's 'wall of death', a very interesting concept that works nicely. Soul King is the one truly competitive game mode, in which no player cooperates with each other at all, since the objective is to eliminate everyone in sight and collect the dropped souls. Soul Survivor is similar, but only one player is selected as a spectre at the beginning of a round, whose objective is to kill the other players and turn them into spectres before the time runs out. All game modes are solid and work well, but will get repetitive after a small amount of time due to the fact that there is only a small selection of maps. I was also turned off by the removal of game modes such as Deathmatch, Capture The Flag, Slow-Mo Team Death Match, and others.ConclusionThe verdict is split. The game for someone who doesn't care for the series is likely to be solid, because the gameplay can be fun if you play it with friends and mess around in the multiplayer. However, as a huge fan of the series I say avoid it at all costs, unless you love Fettel like a fangirl. As a game alone it gets a 6.8/10.0. As a F.E.A.R. game, 1.6/10.0.

												Everyone is like "This is the worst game ever, dont buy it" FEAR 3 is by no means a bad game. It is actually a fantastic and entertaining shooter. People have just been spoiled by how incredible the first FEAR was. FEAR 3 modernized the franchise and simplified a ton of the aspects of the gameplay, but it is 100 times better than FEAR 2. To me, FEAR 3 feels like a modern version of the original FEAR. There is regenrating health, the graphics arn't blurry (im talking to you FEAR 2), you can only hold two weapons, there is a cover system that you dont even have to use if u dont want to... Sure, the story went a bit off road compared to the rest of the games, but Its a great game, give it a try.

y 6, 2015
												This game is absolutely terrible. The devs turned this once awesome horror series into an action oriented co-op shooter.First off the "horror" parts in this game are neither creepy nor frightening, they're simply annoying. FEAR and Project Origin did their job far better in this regard. In addition to describe the A.I. as weak in this game would be an understatement. It was a huge step backwards from the previous games.If you don't play this game in co-op be prepared for very unfair fights. How about fighting a mech with little to no cover or possibilities to avoid damage and your opponent having a huge amount of health and hitting like a truck? Sounds fun doesn't it? (not to me) - The "boss fights" are not really what I'd call challenging as they don't require that much thinking. It's just kill them faster than they can kill you.The story is just a mess. Characters from the previous games don't make any sense and there are plotholes all over the place.Finally from what I saw the multiplayer was dead on arrival. There was only these gauntlet like missions and no real player vs player action. But even in these co-op missions you have to compete against your teammates. If you are to slow or not good enough you will be left behind or have a negative influence on the overall performance. I don't know who designed it, but it wasn't thought out very well.

content:
er 8, 2015
												I guess this game had a pretty large focus on multiplayer, both co-op and competitive, but no one else is playing it so I can only review the single player, which, at it's heart, is a mediocre shooter.  It tries to spice things up with a first person cover mechanic, but it doesn't add very much in terms of usefulness.  In fact, it's a bit wonky and often times hinders you.  There were several times I was hit while "in cover" without being able to see the enemy in front of me.  Fetel's possession and psychic mechanics seemed fun, but you need to complete missions as point man first to unlock him.  I only played him for a few missions.Spooks are pretty half-hearted and sparse in this last installment of the FEAR series.  A big part of that coming from not really interacting with Alma at all.  Nearly all dialogue is given to you through your bro. who is disturbing, but not really scary.  Alma was center stage for FEAR 2, and it's what made for great spooks.  Here you barely feel her presence at all and her personality is nonexistant.  Some sections of the game look very dated graphically.  Much more so than FEAR 2(as I remember it).  Some approaching FEAR 1 levels of meh.  This usually isn't a concern for me, but it has me scratching my head on how much of a graphical downgrade they seem to have had between sequels.The sound design is pretty terrible.  FEAR never really had satisfying gun sounds, but sometimes there will be something that happens in a scripted scene, like a head exploding, and there will be no sound effect paired with it at all.  Pretty immersion breaking.Overall an OK shooter with tepid spooks.4/10

content:
27
												I went into this game expecting nothing, since I heard it didn't hold up against FEAR 1.  Truth is it doesn't, but that didn't stop me from having a great time anyway!FEAR 3 is a pretty standard corridor shooter, at least if you play it as a single player game like I did.  The sound design is great, guns and explosions feels satifyingly punchy.  In one part of the campaign had your character go temporarily deaf due to an explosion for about 5 minutes, at first I thought it was a bug but it works great for the scene, very memorable.  The music is great as well, it really enhances some of the spooky bits.Some of the environments are downright inspired, level 2 where you're fighting cultists in a costco TV electronics section that looks like a hall of mirrors is a standout moment.  Making your way through crashed train cars on a collapsing bridge was another great scene.  The level where you're fighting your way through cultist martial law suburbia is like a dark take on Modern Warefare 2's levels in the same setting.  Whoever put the shower jumpscare in the game, congrats, that one got me good.The difficulty is definitely skewed for consoles, play on the hardest difficulty and it's fun.    Didn't run into any bugs on my playthrough, although a few sections were next to impossible to complete without abusing the AI.  The enemies are dumb cannon fodder in this game, nothing like FEAR 1.  Playthrough took maybe 7-8 hours.In short, it's a fairly standard shooter with some brilliant environments.  I'd give it a shot if you enjoy single player fps games and can get it for cheap.

content:
y 16, 2015
												Every time I see FEAR 3 on sale I see people bashing it as the worst in the series, but the meta score is actually not too bad 74/100. Unlike the first 2 FEAR games, FEAR 3 has one of those regenerating health systems where you just hide under cover for a few seconds and you recover back to full health. No need to scrounge for med kits or armor. Also, the game seems built around 2 player co-op, which I like in first person shooter games (when I have someone to play with).*Spoilers ahead*FEAR 3 takes place an unspecified amount of time after the events of FEAR 2. Alma is pregnant and getting ready to give birth, as a result her psychic power is tearing up the city (possibly the world). Again the main opposition is the private military contractor Armacham, who seems to have become 100x more powerful than they were in the first games. Even without their clone super soldiers from the first games, Armacham seems capable of overrunning and occupying entire cities with soldiers, aircraft, and power armor. You play the Point Man protagonist from the first FEAR game (the guy you play in FEAR 2 also shows up briefly) but this time you have an “imaginary” friend Paxton Fettel (Bad guy from the first game). Your primary goal this time around is to reach Alma before she gives birth and deal with her once and for all. Unfortunately for you, Alma’s psychic pain has summoned nightmare creatures and twisted the surviving civilian population into crazed psychos.Unlike the previous FEAR games, FEAR 3 is broken down into missions or “levels” with each mission giving you a point score at the end. You gain points by finding collectables, killing enemies, and completing “challenges.” The challenges are similar to the “Skill shots” in Bulletstorm, where it’s basically just using various methods of killing. For example, 2000 points for killing enemies with a specific weapon, or 1000 points for getting 25 headshots, or 2000 points for getting 3 backstabs. The points aren’t just for show, by the way. You “level up” when you gain enough points and each level gives you some kind of perk, such as +10% health or +bullet capacity. You can replay levels as many times as you want to “grind” for points. This means that the game will get easier over time as you replay it. You might notice that when you first start the game, it seems far more difficult than the previous ones, well this changes as you level up and get stronger. The regenerating health means you can charge groups of enemies and just duck for cover when your screen is almost completely red (near death). Healing is free unlike FEAR 1 and 2 which had limited med kits.As I mentioned earlier, the game is built with 2 player co-op in mind. At the end of each mission there is a ranking between the 2 players to see who scored highest in several categories. The game’s ending depends on which of the two characters “won” the most missions. Of course if you’re playing single player the character you’re playing (Fettel or Point Man) will “win” every level you complete. Point Man’s gameplay is the same as the previous games (standard shooter with Slow-Mo power), But Fettel is a psychic commander. This means he can possess enemies and use them to fight (he doesn’t have slow-mo). Every time he takes over a new body he gets the weapons of the possessed enemy, so you can’t hoard powerful weapons or grenades the way Point Man does. You can only hold 2 weapons now, unlike 3 weapons in FEAR 1 and 4 weapons in FEAR 2. Possession also means you won’t be able to use the awesome power armors because the possessed body won’t last long enough. Pros:+Excellent graphics and visuals. Large variety of weapons available.+Some cool new enemies, particular the Phase Commander and Phase Caster.+A lot of replay value. I just finished the game and immediately restarted as Fettel. +2 player co-op available. Also a bunch of various multiplayer game modes I haven’t tried.Cons:-The game is very short, about 6 hours to beat the first time. Replay is strongly encouraged though.-The story is weaker than the first FEAR games. There’re a lot of unnecessary “dream sequences” that don’t seem to add much. You just walk forward about 15 seconds with someone talking in voice over and it ends.-I get the feeling that the enemies are much “dumber” than FEAR 1 enemies. They tend to stick behind the same piece of cover and just pop their heads out to shoot from there.Overall I think the game is well worth playing for fans of First Person Shooters and people who want to see how the FEAR story ends. Once you finish a mission in single player, the Fettel character is unlocked so you can try playing him for that particular level. The way to see the Fettel game ending is by playing through the game a second time (or play the game in co-op and Fettel has the highest score every mission). One thing I noticed is that the game’s Steam achievements seem to be half for multiplayer, and not many people are playing the multiplayer. This isn’t surprising since the game has been out for a few years. I’ll probably only be able to get about 45% completion for the game achievements by myself.

content:
4, 2016
												"How the mighty have fallen", said Pius Augustus to Mantorok. I think the same applies here. The first FEAR was a "visceral" FPS, offering an honest challenge and a great atmosphere. FEAR2 was much less horror, more streamlined, but still OK.Alas, a common plague in the video game industry is the need to make trilogies, when it's uncalled for or there is not enough substance for it- or both. F3AR falls in this category. Sure, the fate of Alma was still hanging after the end of the previous game, but this one has nothing to tell. Story has not to be the strong point of a FPS, but when it's that shallow, it impacts the game itself.F3AR is very short (5 to six hours) with only 8 levels, two of wich are fillers (the store after the first crash, the bridge after the second crash) and the last is an dream-like stage, glorified string of mini-cutscenes culminating with the destruction of Harlan Wade (wich, of course, is a giant abomination with a glowing weak point). So the only goal is to rejoin Alma whose psychic contractions are bringing doom to Fairport and its surroundings. F3AR fails what I like to call the Teleportation Test : when a story can be resolved with just the protagonist(s) being teleported to a certain location. And it's exactly the case with F3AR. There is no need for character development, nothing to seek or activate, nothing to accomplish really, just go see Mother. Jin (who, because Plot, is now dear to Pointman's heart ?) is just needed to pinpoint a certain location and is discaded afterwards. Now, of course, all this could be forgiven with brilliant gameplay. No such luck here. Using Pointman's slow-mo power is still fun, but kinda loses its edge after two games. Weaponry doesn't have anything outstanding, apart maybe for the impaler thingie, and even using mechas is not as fun as it could be. The level-design is dull and makes for a very, very linear progression. Of course you gather ammo, otherwise, the only things to seek are corpses to "consume"... For points. Doing certain feats (headshots...) also grant you points, and every now and then you will "level-up" to gain new skills (that you can't choose, of course). If you play in co-op, points also determine who will be the favorite son, hence deciding the ending. The first player is Pointman, the other one is Fettel, who can blast psychic rays and possess people, giving a bit more fun. This co-op option is a good thing, because I sincerely think it's the only way to get some real enjoyment from the game. As far as I tried, multiplayer is dead and the campaign has little to no replay value. My advice ? If you want a few laughs, wait for a -75% discount, find a friend to play it with during a rainy afternoon and call it a day. Of, and course, even if the game tries to be creepy, forget about the horror feeling of the first game. Here, it's mainly Doomsday mixed with mad men, some gore and demons.

To wrap this review up, the game is worth $5 and no more than that. If you like interesting stories full of gore and are fans of previous F.E.A.R. games then I recommend you get this immediately. Also, if you play with a friend it is probably 100x the fun compared to playing by yourself. If I were to rate this game, it'd probably be a solid 7/10. Could have been worse, could have been better.

content:
ry 21, 2016
												I loved the first two games in the F.E.A.R. franchise. I loved the insane action, slow-motion roundhouse kicks and bodies exploding into Jell-O(tm) when you pumped a shell into them. I loved the freaky-deaky story, the mysterious protagonist(s) and the occasional flirt with enigmatic storytelling, the screeching, violin-falling-down-the-stairs soundtrack that worked in all its beautiful discordance and hair-raising abruptness. The scripted scares wove ladders, hallways, doors and windows into shockingly intricate little spookouts that contrasted with the bombastic shootouts that framed them, and it all just worked out so WELL. Hell, even the ending of the second game was pretty good in my eyes.And then this game. Oh boy.I hardly know what to say about it, and I hardly have the energy- even now- to summon a full-blown rant on this marvelous marvelous deconstruction of a once-great shooter franchise. The scares? Gone. The lonesome eeriness? Gone. Hope you like playing co-operatively with your psychic *** brother who has lost all of his charm now that you can see how he works and he's always trotting along beside you like a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ doberman. The Half-Life-esque presentation that kept you in the protagonist's perspective constantly and almost never thrust you into immersion-punching cutscenes? Hope you didn't like them, because apparently neither did WB. Did I mention that this game isn't scary?It gets most of the action from previous titles right, but it's more than just lacking in the horror department. The game called... CALLED... 'Fear'? It doesn't even try to be scary. At all.

content:
r 24, 2014
												F.E.A.R. 3 is a First Person Horror Shooter.It continues the story line of F.E.A.R. 1 and 2 but here you are again the protagonist from the first game.The Point Man, one of Almas childs. And actually you can play 2 characters, the other one being Paxton Fettel, the other son of Alma, but only when you have finished the game once. There are 2 different endings. The first, which is probably the "real" ending is the good one of the Point Man and the other one is the Evil end of Paxton Fettel.The Story itself is easy explained. You have to reach Alma because she is giving birth to her new child.But this is a hard and stony way especially because you have to escape from a prison first but because both brothers working together it works. Working together more or less. But beside you are hunted by your bad memories of your childhood which feature Harlan Wade, the "father" of Alma. Saying father is this case is an insult because he is a real ****, well you know what I mean. You have to forget your memories of Harlan Wade.On your way you pass many levels and especially different ones! No level looks the same and this is actually what was really amazing! Never saw so much variety and nice design in the levels. Pretty much the best from all F.E.A.R. games but this is probably the only aspect thats better compared to other games, sadly.The game implemented a new Health system what I like to call CoD illness. Really annoying and I missed the Medipacks and armor. It wasnt that bad after all but seriously, why did you have to add this feature to a F.E.A.R. game?There is also a new level system which I like to call CoD level illness. You get XP for getting Kill rewards or collecting things. Never liked it but to be honest its not that bad implemented here. With "ranking" up you also get new Skills or upgrades. While playing this game I noticed that this game is pretty much build up for Multiplayer or Coop. Annoyed me a bit to be honest, I hate games where Singleplayer campaigns doesnt feel like Singleplayer campaigns.For me this game was a little bit difficult sometimes, I played on Normal difficulty. But this difficulty was more because of the damn bloodscreen. I hate this and it makes the game hectic.The scare level is a little bit less I have to say but there were still some nice level parts which scared me. Not as many as before though. You are not hunted by Alma in this game anyway. Alma got nearly friendly, I really like how the developers changed Alma. For me she was never that evil anyway, I even liked her. She had just a bad history.[SPOILER!] (I try to let them out but in this case I have to say it because its a bad thing for me about the game)But what really made me sad is the fact that Alma dies in the end anyway, why letting the main character die like this? If you play the game you know what I mean. A really stupid and wasted death for Alma. I hope her child can offer us a similar experience in F.E.A.R. 4, if it will be ever released. Cant tell actually. Maybe this was the final game. Also Becket dies in a poor and questionable way... WHY? This didnt even make any sense. Especially how they made Becket. I mean the 1-2 minutes he actually appears in a cutscene. Yeah, the character was silent in F.E.A.R. 2 but here they just made him like a poor ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ which wants to end his miserable life. Couldnt they make something more interesting like he teamed up with Alma or something? Its his child after all... Bad decision. They could have made the story so much better.The graphics of the game are ok but nothing special. Similar to F.E.A.R. 2s graphics.It has to be said that this game was developed by another studio, not Monolith.Monolith just provided some help. The main developer was Day 1 Studios.Noticeable concerning the changes but wasnt that bad for a indie sort of developer.I had time to play the campaign in coop with my girlfriend.It was actually a little bit more enjoyable in coop, especially playing with Fettel.First time I played with him and it was a completely different gameplay.You can actually move into enemies bodies and control them. This is only for a limited time though. But you can extend it with collecting their souls after they die.When you are not inside of an enemy you can shoot some sort of projectiles from your hand.You can also grab your enemies from far away. I actually had quite some fun playing in Coop.In the end there is a comparison of the statistics of both players and who actually wins the playthrough. This characters ending is played then. I personally felt like Fettel was more powerful than the Pointman. Unbalanced maybe, no clue.This is where the game actually proper shines in my opinion.And this is actually the only reason for me to replay it sometimes...Never the less, Singleplayer is just mediocre.Postitive:- Nice variety of environments in levels- Solid shooter gameplay, little bit similar to F.E.A.R. 2s.- Some scares, not as many as before- Good Coop- Fettel is a interesting gameplay characterNegative:- Too... Much... CoD...- Levels/Ranks useless beside of Coop- Questionable story decisions- Singleplayer is kinda boring, made for Coop...- 5 Hour campaign- Graphics outdated (2011)- Soundtrack is different and worse- Probably the last F.E.A.R. ever... F.E.A.R. Online just made it worse.Replayability: Only for CoopWell, thats everything that needs to be said I think.F.E.A.R. 3 was a good game for me but with a little bitter taste, especially at the end.It didnt feel like a proper F.E.A.R. anymore. Only replayable for Coop.The story is actually kind of disappointing. The devs totally wasted a lot of potencial here.Why did Monolith give this game away to another developer? Seriously? Actually I feel like they killed the franchise with this action. Or maybe it was WB who wanted to milk the franchise to death?I hope you take responsibility for this Monolith or WB. This is how you NOT do it.Well, the devs of F.E.A.R. 3 still did somewhat a solid job, even if the end product is far away from the quality of the first 2 F.E.A.R.s.My rating would be 6.5/10 points.The other games, except the addons/dlcs got always better ratings.I think this is a fair score and I cant give more without feeling to overrate it.

The first part of this game had an outstanding graphics for the date of its release, it had a lot of moments which would make you turn grey. But here you can see no particular graphics (but i should say that it is not too awful). No real moments that are to scare you, just some nervous screams will put you out for a moment. The plot is rather interesting, but it could be better, The first part was even more technological than this one, excepting an ability to use battle robo machines. If you like challenge (i had an ability to trace it there) and a rain of bullets - this game is for you. Still I would advise you to take this game while it is on sale - the price is too high for its presentation.

content:
er 21, 2014
												So i have beat this on console and bought it on sale to play some of the co-op with my friend when it was 75% off. The co-op is fun but virtually any game that isn’t flat awful or broken is pretty fun with friends. There are two characters with different game play, the series original Point Man and Paxton Fettel. Here are the pros and cons of the PC version.Pros- Paxton Fettel is really fun to play as with unique and fun interesting paranormal abilities like possession.- Has a Co-op campaign- A nice achievement and upgrade system- You have a nice set of customizable controls with secondary bindings for all functions- Nice sound options with multiple slidersCons- Simple console like FPS cover based shooting. Press Q then arrows to pop out from cover shoot use bullet time to change cover repeat- Instead of mildly tactical squad based combat you push through a crowed, fight a hoard, push through crowd again. - Fairly linear with much less alternative routes then the two predecessors- The bullet time for point man is essentially useless and just thrown in because it is part of the series- Not a great port with some bad low res textures and limited graphics options- Super unbalanced Riot shield, find it, win- for the price a little too short. Took me almost 7 hours on console to beat- Multiplayer is pretty much dead and was tacked on anyway- Simple contrived plot- Adds nothing to the story of the franchise and in fact is kind of an insult to fans not that the other two had great ones, but it doesn’t fit into the universe (if you don’t care about story like me though that doesn’t matter much)- Horrible main character ,rugged, scruffy, boring, robotic, bad ♥♥♥, action hero template number 4 instead of the silent protagonist (again you can get past that easily but if that stuff matters to you it will probably disappoint)My verdictGeneric and not worth your time; It is another drop in the sea of mediocrity. Play F.E.A.R or F.E.A.R 2 instead, they are both much better games in every aspect. Unless you get it on a good sale to mess around with as Paxton Fettel it isn’t worth your time or money.

content:
y 12, 2014
												If you are the type of person that doesn’t like to read a long review, then I will provide you with a short description which properly conveys the message of my full-review. DON’T BUY THIS GAME expecting the same type of game play as the previous F.E.A.R installments. HOWEVER IF YOU LIKE THROWING AWAY MONEY AND PLAYING A BADLY PORTED COD STYLE FPS FOR P_SSIES THAT LIKE TO HIDE BEHIND COVER 90% OF THE TIME I HIGHLY RECOMMEND IT. OK, now that this is said, I shall begin with my full-review of the game. First off, I would like to point out that I have played both F.E.A.R and F.E.A.R 2 and had a blast of a time while playing them. I really loved the style of the games, and I would say that F.E.A.R. 1 is the best out of the entire series.Now onto F.E.A.R 3 …The game starts with some nice cut-scenes that manage to get me all hyped up to play another F.E.A.R.  game. As soon as these cut-scenes end I get the mission to escape from a prison. At that point I could already tell that the game has a different feel to it, like it wasn’t as dark as the previous games.  But I didn’t care about that and continue playing. So after walking out of my prison cell the game starts explaining the controls and after killing a guard I get my first gun.  Now I am ready to once again become a bad 4ss MOF0 and bust some caps, or so I thought…NOPE NOPE NOPE.jpeg; As soon as the action starts and I end up in my first shootout the game explains that you need to use Q to hide.  Now.. hiding isn’t that bad I mean it’s logical to hide to avoid ending up like Swiss cheese.  But this game brings it to a whole new level, the being a little p_ssy level.  The map is obviously designed so you have to hide behind every other f_cking box. And as soon as you get shot, you lose an unknown amount of health and you can simply regenerate it by hiding for 5 f_cking seconds.  So where is the challenge to managing your health by using the med kits like in the previous games?  And why are we hiding all the f_cking time, point man used to be a bad 4ss.  OK this is also the moment I start to feel like the game wasn’t developed for the PC and is actually a cheap port. So even with all of that going on I continue my escape from prison whilst encountering several shootouts and getting annoyed about the whole continuously hiding behind boxes and having the unnatural feeling of playing a bad port.  This goes on for a while and I finally decide that this game is a piece of sh!t.. and I got better games to play.So how did the fear series end up with this piece of sh!t? It’s because this game wasn’t even developed by the same company that developed the initial fear games.  NOPE not developed by Monolith but by Day 1 Studios. Anyhow thank the seven gods that I bought this game in a steam sale and did not have to pay full price. Because after just about 15 minutes of play time I decided it was a piece of sh_t and uninstalled the game. And I didn’t even get to die once.. So I guess you are practically immortal in this game as long as you hide behind boxes.

content:
r 1, 2016
												Pure and utter garbage.F.E.A.R 3 Ultima Ascension of the FEAR franchise. After but 5 minutes the plot collapses in on itself and twists and turns a previous tactical shooter into a CoD clone for 10 year olds. The Gameplay is average. Gone is still the uber shotgun from FEAR 1 and so is the enemy AI. The game is so easy on next to hardest difficulty Fearless, and the hardest one being Insane which is locked until you finish the game at least once. No effort was required of me as I blasted enemies to dust and only died when I was either stupid or engaged in honorable melee with the enemy.The levels are boring and repetitive, and the level transition will leave you confused. At an early point in the game, you are trying to flee the city, and get shot down while doing so, and after crashing you immediately return to the city. What!? Oh, also, Point Man crashes, explodes and falls from mortal heights and still survives, It's a cliché nowadays but it's still complete garbage to look at. Levels consists of open areas with enemies spawning around a small map. Kill enemies, proceed through a corridor to the next big area, and repeat. It's also that annoying kind of map that won't allow you to jump over things the devs don't want you to jump over! Want to jump over this couch? Can't do that. Want to crouch under this railing? Can't do that. But you can only crouch under the only thing that will continue the on rail shooting segments. The pacing is ♥♥♥♥ as well, there is no time for you to breath out between battles, no puzzles of any kind exists other then, press button, open door kind. Not like you'll ever get worked up playing this PoS since the scary/creepy parts are all but gone. If this game didn't have FEAR in the name I would never have associated it with the series att all.Story collapsed in on itself after about 5 minutes. Why answer questions like: Where are we? Why am I here? What am I suppose to do? Point Man apparently has character now, which is funny since he's a silent MP, so It's stupid. Also Fettel now apparently thinks family is super important and now wants to help you/you help him to get you to mother. Why is he there? Is another question I asked myself since you did put a bullet in his head in the first game. And now he is ghost, or, something, but still needs to walk through doors. I don't care anymore, why should I when the devs didn't care either. Also dead characters are alive as well that died in FEAR Extraction Point expansion for the first game but I guess, RETCON! Didn't happen, character is alive now, hurray! Or the expansion simply weren't canon, but FEAR 2's dlc was! Cuz Fettel.Kuk fitt spel. One of the worst sequels I've played, it fails on every level, and It's not even fun on a terribad level. Just bad all around and makes you sad that It's a part of a far greater series.

content:
r 16, 2014
												Just beat F.E.A.R. 3, making me beat every single F.E.A.R. game, okay review time, this game, while not bad, was good in aspects and bad at everything else. let alone, as a fan of the series, this game was kinda a let down too me. I enjoyed the fast pace combat, but it took out all stragity that made the first and second games a hard deal, you actual had to plan out your combat route, know when to use slow-mo, and keep ur wits on guard, Playing as paxton can be pretty fun aswell, as it's a diffrent kinda play to the Series. slo-mo in F.E.A.R. 3 had sometimes almost no propose because by time u use it, its gone already, F.E.A.R. 3 compared to the others had minimum to no horror aspect, no dark atmosphere, and quite frankly, the story line was poor and kinda boring. they tried to escalate the matter of the situation, without telling us why it's happening. Taking out the replica forces made NO sense to me, and they never Evan explain why there not there, i mean they were in 2, and still being controlled, so why not in 3, and why the ♥♥♥♥ is point man in captivity when at the end of F.E.A.R. 1 he escaped with his team. F.E.A.R. 3 has beautiful graphics, smooth game play, brutal combat, and an interesting Ranking system. As for story line, atmosphere, tone, and excitability, it was a huge let down, i have to say by far F.E.A.R. 2 was the best in the series. F.E.A.R. 3 just feels more like call of duty when it trys to be creepy. this is a great stand alone game, esp for FPS fans, but for personal fans of the F.E.A.R. Series as a whole, this is just a disappointment. hopefully, if they make another game, they will try to make it less "Call of dutyish" and return to the Dark, disturbing, amazing storyline that F.E.A.R. use to be. What they gained in making fast paced action game play, made it less horror, and less stragidy and more just shoot shoot shoot. and where are my martial arts melee attacks that were so fun to pull off. like i said though, good standalone game, but with the F.E.A.R. logo, its a let downStandalone game: 7/10F.E.A.R. Game: 4/10
