content:
r 21, 2015
												Rating 7/10Overview: FPS with the ability to go into slow-mo The Good+ The game features 2 main characters you can play as. You first have to complete the game as 'point man'. This character allows you to slow down time while you blast away your enemies. The other character is Paxton Fettel who has the ability to possess almost any enemy in the game. + A cover based system in a first person shooter never seems to work out, yet this game handles the feature nicely. With a single press of a button  you can hide behind cover and easily pop out and shoot your enemies. + By completing challenges you acquire experience which is then used to level up your character. Challenges include killing a certain amount of enemies with a weapon, getting headshots, staying in slow-mo for a certain amount of time etc. It's a nice addition and it helps you change up your play style so you're not constantly relying on the same tricks over and over again. + I feel the AI has improved (yet still lacking to the first FEAR), enemies flank, hide, take cover and feel like a genuine threat when facing them. +Variety of different weapons and grenades+The shooting mechanics feel good, going into slow-mo and shooting enemies is always fun. The game also introduces sections where you ride a mech to change up the gameplay.The Average:On a technical level the graphics are decent. Textures are solid, lighting and shadows look decent however artistically the game feels bland and uninspired. Poor color usage and levels that feel and look the same despite being in different environments doesn't help either. The story is decent but it really is starting to feel convoluted at this point. Game will provide around 5-7 hours for one playthrough. Multiplayer and playing through the campaign as the second character can extend playtime for a bit. The game features some multiplayer modes that can be played in single player and extend your game time. The problem is that multiplayer is dead which is sad given that some of these modes looks really fun to play.The Bad- multiplayer is dead which also means getting certain achievements is now impossible- no local co-opConclusionThe more FEAR games we get the farther we move away from what made the original so great. This game lacks even less horror elements and tactical shooting from the previous entries and is essentially a straight up first person shooter with the slow-mo ability. I don't consider this a bad game but compared to the last 2 entries it feels like it took 2 steps back and 1 step forward.

content:
er 26, 2013
												F.E.A.R. 3 is a fun and well polished shooter, IF you're looking for a fun casual experience a la Call of Duty, but do NOT mistake it for a sequel to the excellent F.E.A.R.. The gameplay has now become a mix of Parkour and fast paced gunfights, the goal being to make the highest score by replaying the same levels, over and over.Interestingly, the campaign can be played in co-op, but this makes the game a little too easy, so I would recommend to finish the game in solo first. The game also features some very original multiplayer game modes. In F*king Run, up to six players are tasked to escape from an ever advancing fog of death, while the players are being pursued by an increasing number and tougher enemies. This game mode is exceptionally fun and challenging. Contractions is a survival mode tasking the players to barricade themselves from waves of possessed enemies. Unfortunately, nowadays it's impossible to find anybody playing multiplayer games or the cooperative campaign.

number of helpful: 8 of 16 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
er 9, 2014
												One of the best co-op experiences, endings and credits song ever! Atmospheric horror shooting with two characters from which to choose – each for different playing style. Good graphics and tactical advancement. Also, F.E.A.R.3 has one of the most reasonable achievement system on Steam. The balanced, fast-paced gameplay and intriguing story will keep you going from the beginning until the end for the first walktrough, which takes only about 6-7 hours. But it's not a problem. After the first time, you can take the other character or try multiplayer. Still feels great.The multiplayer is ok, but nothing exciting.Despite some managable technical problems, it's one of my favourite games.Overall rating: 10/10.NB!There are few technical tweaks you should know, before you play this game.1. First, rename ClientRegistry.blob file to ClientRegistryOld.blob (Steam folder). This might save you from kicking out, when there are too many players on server (happens around sales time).2. Manually adjust the FOV, by opening the options.cfg file (game folder) and deleting the # tag and changing value to 85. This will save you from dizziness.

												EDIT: After digging a little through Google, I found you can disable motion blur through the options.cfg in the installation directories root folder. Now I can recommend this game.Original:Plays well from what I have seen. Fun Co-op, but I can't recommend this game. The motion blur and FOV aren't able to change and cause to me to become extremely motion sick when playing and I have to take breaks every 10-20 minutes so I don't throw up. If you don't get motion sick, then this game is worth the purchase when it is discounted.

content:
24, 2014
												I really couldn't bring myself to finish F.E.A.R. 3. It was so lacklustre in comparison to its far superior predecessors, to the point where it was simply the stuff from my nightmares.Gunplay in F.E.A.R. 3 is sluggish and boring. While the guns sound impressive, I find the aiming and movement mechanics to be too wavy for my tastes. Getting a bead on enemies is awkward, saved only by the Slo-Mo mechanic that was also present in the previous two games. Even adjusting the sensitivity failed to improve anything. When playing arcadey-style shooters, I expect fast, fluid and responsive combat. F.E.A.R. 3 has none of that.Graphically, the game is laughable, looking like an Xbox 360/PS3 launch title at best. The atmosphere is foggy and ugly, and is nowhere near as immersive as the dark, claustrophobia-inducing corridors and areas that the original F.E.A.R. harboured. The game is completely lacking in the horror department, resorting only to cheap jump scares instead of the subtle, eerie hallucinations and sound effects that the made the first game so terrifying. Even the presence of a bloodied, heavily pregnant Alma failed to make me jump and cower behind my chair in terror.Multiplayer is quite fun. F**king Run is intense and challenging enough on its own, but the sluggish gunplay made experiencing it nothing short of a nightmare; no pun intended. On the plus side, most servers were lag-free and performed reasonably well.Apologies for the short review, but I really can’t say much more about F.E.A.R. 3. The game was so boring and awkward to play that I simply couldn’t bring myself to play more than a few hours of it. Half-decent multiplayer and a woeful singleplayer campaign does not justify a playthrough, even at the €5 price tag that I bought this game at. A waste of money and time. It truly is the black sheep of the F.E.A.R. series, and anyone who enjoyed the previous two iterations would do well to stay away from this tosh.Being one of the worst FPS games I have played in recent memory, F.E.A.R. 3 gets a 3/10.

content:
r 4, 2014
												This game was incredibly disappointing. The push towards console gaming is made even more apparant with the 3rd iteration in the FEAR franchise, a game that completely abandons everything that made the original such a classic. The gameplay has been oversimplified and while it's cliche to say it's like a "COD" game now, it quite literally is. I'm not exactly sure why this game is even called "FEAR" because this game was less scary than Octodad. The story is completely idiotic it could easily be compared to something like Sharknado. And the graphics have suffered a significant amount, looking worse than the original game that came out almost a decade before it. Let's talk about the gameplay in more detail though...First off, the game is much more fast paced. You're given the ability to sprint, slide, vault, and worst of all, "take cover." This game mechanic is so incredibly annoying. Basically if you are near any vertical surface and decide you want to crouch, the game will automatically snap you to cover. This will lock you into position until you hit the crouch button again, meaning you have to stand up in the middle of a firefight just to relocate your position. The game also offers a new and completely unnecessary "ranking" system that constantly gives you these big cheesy notifications whenever you kill a certain amount of enemies in a row with headshots or something. This franchise is about walking around in dark hallways, shooting enemies in slow motion, and being scared silly by some creepy girl in the shadows. FEAR 3 seems to have forgotten all of that. Every level in the game seems to take place in broad daylight, and even when you do go inside a dark building, the ambient lighting is so bright you can see the terrible textures in every dark corner. Now don't get me wrong, the gunplay is more fun than it has ever been, but because of this focus on improving combat, the game's identity has been completely lost. Even the few times that you do see the creepy girl "Alma," it's almost comical... like seeing her riding on the opposite escalator, looking confused as to why she no longer was scaring me. Another major downside to the game is the most immediate thing you'll probably notice, "health regen." That's right, they finally did away with the classic refreshing "health-kits" that make games so much more intense and opted for the "COD" approach where you can inhale bullets, take cover for half a second, and then jump out from cover good as new. This along with the near endless supply of ammo for every gun has taken away any type of suspense left in this game. I was able to cruise through this game without any real problems at all in less than half the time it took me to beat the original FEAR. So while the game is fast-paced and fun shooter by itself, FEAR fans will want to avoid this entirely due to the complete lack of horror. Now let's talk about the story. It sucks. It's just so painfully bad. Basically it starts off with the stupid ending from FEAR 2 where ALMA somehow rapes a guy (yes... according to the FEAR developers, a woman can now ♥♥♥♥ a man) and is now pregnant and going into labor. In FEAR 3, you take on the role of the original character, who I guess is named "Point-Man" and are tasked with trying to stop ALMA from having this evil baby. Your brother that you shot in the head in the first game is somehow, without explanation, back... and is now constantly on your shoulder the entire game, spoiling all of the mystery and suspense behind everything that happens. "Uh oh.. sounds like ALMA is here, she's probably going to jump out at you brother!" your brother will say as you walk into a new area. In addition to his terrible voice acting, your forced to listen to these frustrating loud screams that are supposed to be ALMA going into labor, but just sound like poorly done fake ♥♥♥♥♥♥ sounds and they sound absolutely ridiculous. Thankfully this train-wreck of a story ends quickly, with some completley random and unexplained player rank-based ending that I guess is affected by how well you played throughout the game? You're never given any warning about this so it was really confusing once I reached the end. If you're a fan of FEAR's storyline, I suggest you avoid this... avoid this like the plague. You're better off watching Alien 4 or something...Graphics are another pretty big deal when it comes to FEAR games. The original FEAR was one of the best looking games available in its time with revolutionary physics, shadows, and fantastic lighting. FEAR 3 is quite the opposite. I'm surprised games post-2010 can even look this bad. The lighting is all static, with hardly any dynamic nature at all to the environment in any sense (meaning no more cool slow motion physics based destruction). The gore is laughable, with enemies just exploding into tiny blood shaded explosions when you shoot them with a shotgun, and even on the highest possible settings, the texture resolutions were just painful to look at. The FEAR franchise has certainly fallen from grace in the graphics department. It's frustrating seeing a franchise die so quickly with obvious shifts towards a more action oriented, COD friendly consumer base, and the FEAR franchise is a perfect example of this. What once was a hardcore, scary, action shooter with no health-regen and some impressive visuals has now turned into a Call of Duty game with a different franchise's logo pasted onto the cover. FEAR 3's gameplay is fun, fast paced, and hectic, but this just wasn't a necessary change. The game's horror has been completely abandoned and the storyline feels like an afterthought. This along with the games lazy graphic design are all reasons I just simply can't recommend buying this game. Maybe if the entire franchise is on sale it's worth it for a short afternoon killing spree, but I wouldn't expect much that's for sure.

You will kill enemy soldiers and make your move, like in the previous versions you have the ability to slow down time, also known as "Bullet time". When taking damage your screen will become red. content:
7, 2015
												This game wasn't actually made by Monolith; it was developed by Day One Studios, the studio that was previously only responsible for making the console ports of FEAR 1 and its expansions. It shows, in a lot of ways. The levels are much more linear, you're limited to two weapons, and the graphics are arguably worse than FEAR 2's and maybe even FEAR 1's. The story is barely coherent at best (which isn't helped by the fact that despite FEAR 3 having actual cutscenes, Pointman is still a silent protagonist who only communicates through furiously scrunching his eyebrows), and you don't even get a clear goal or an idea of where you're actually going until around halfway through the game's 4 hour campaign. The only aspect of the game that's anything interesting is the co-op system, in which the two players are cooperating but still loosely competing against each other to decide which ending they get, which works a lot better than it does in games that somehow manage to be even worse than this one like Call of Juarez: The Cartel. And that's a good thing, because the only way I can recommend even considering playing this game is if you have a friend to play it with, though even then it's only a loose recommendation since this game is really only that fun under the "any game is fun with a friend" rule. This game barely has enough content to be a hard sell if it were priced at $10 or $15 like the first two games are, but at $20 it's absolutely not worth picking up unless you just really want to suffer through an evening with a friend and have expended all other available options.

content:
er 5, 2013
												I have a lot of gripes with where Day 1 Studios went with the story and tone, but the gameplay of F.E.A.R. 3 is as fun as the series has ever been. F.E.A.R. 1 and 2 are much more well-rounded and sensibly designed, but F.E.A.R. 3 does have co-op. Yes, it does have co-op. Designing the campaign with co-op in mind is probably the main culprit for why F.E.A.R. 3's story/campaign isn't quite as great as the other two's. It ends weird and kind of anti-climactically too. But, it does have co-op.The combat is just about as deliciously good as the other games in the series though, so despite its odd disappointments in terms of how it concluded the series, it should still be a fun romp for anyone who liked the other F.E.A.R. games. It's mostly the same in that regard, although with rank challenges (a sort of points system) and noticeably less scary. Playing as Paxton Fettel is also a cool spin on things that adds replayability. And the rank challenges (which is in all modes) add an extra layer of fun.Also, Alma's just ugly in this one... :(

content:
4, 2016
												I just finished the co-op campaign literally 5 minutes ago, and it was so epic that I just had to write a review. I didn't play the first two games because I'm a ♥♥♥♥♥, so this will be a review for this game only, not comparing it to the other titles.Now for the people wondering how scary this is, there are some tense moments, and some slight scares like suddenly Alma or a monster pops up, but no flashes or screamers or whatever. I think the best part of the game is the fact that you can play co-op campaign, where each player can play as one of the two brothers. The combat is fairly simple, as Point man you just shoot, as Fettel you use your powers to get into enemies bodies for a period of time, lift them up, give Point man shields, that kind of stuff. It's a lot of fun to play together, I really enjoyed it a lot.Now for the story, there was a lot of story in here, I got a fairly good idea of what was going on. It was pretty interesting, but also confusing at times, probably because I haven't played the two previous games. I would love to, but I don't want a heart attack or ♥♥♥♥ my pants.TL;DR:Get this game if you want a good and interesting shooter, especially enjoyable with co-op. 10/10 for me.

content:
14, 2015
												This is a bad shooter that barely belongs in the F.E.A.R. storyline. The second game was tolerable and even good at points but this one makes you wonder why you're not just doing anything else instead. The second mission felt like a bad rip-off of the favela fights in a much better FPS game, and the constant pop-ups for minor achievements are incredibly irritating. For what should theoretically be a relatively slow-paced shooter with bouts of action this one misses the mark completely, and it even throws in regenerating health to hammer the point home. It's like the difference between the Pripyat levels in STALKER and in Modern Warfare - despite having similar themes the feel of them is completely different. This feels barely like the second game and nothing at all like the original. After the favela mission I looked at the "Challenge board" and the "target time" of the mission and decided that it wasn't worth continuing. If I hadn't gotten the game as part of a cheap bundle I wouldn't have even bothered getting that far. I feel sorry for anyone who paid full price for this.

content:
14, 2014
												Well, a great dissapointment has befallen me within the first 10 minutes of playing this game.  I was a huge fan of F.E.A.R. , F.E.A.R. Extraction Point,  F.E.A.R. Perseus Mandate, and knowing how sequels often get dilluted in the development process, I was surprised to see that F.E.A.R. 2 is just as good as the original with actual improvements to the lighting, sound, and gameplay that don't detriment the trademark ambience of the classic F.E.A.R., which makes sense because the entire franchise up to this point was developed by Monolith as a competitive PC market shooter.  Unfortunately,   F.E.A.R. 3 offers none of this.   Because it's a blatant console port.   The lighting is absolutely horrid.  There's some ridiculous grainy mist all over the place which apparently  serves to dress up the fact that the architecture and lighting are completely inadequate for a game in this series, and why is that?  Because it was developed for underpowered fanboy consoles.  F.E.A.R. 1 had better graphics than this, because it was developed for PCs that came out BEFORE PS3, and XBOX 360, which strongly underlines the fact of how pathetic consoles and their games are.  The storyline is completely thrown out the window on this one too. There's no explanation of how Pointman ended up in a prison cell, but we're supposed to be pacified by the appearance of a badly animated cartoon-like Fettel with a  bullet which miraculously stopped in a crater on his forehead. Odd, because I distinctly remember blowing his brains completely out in F.E.A.R. Is this a way to help the clueless console fanboys who didn't play the first two F.E.A.R. games figure out that Fettel was killed by a gunshot to the head and Pointman did it?  Apparently so.  But let's not neglect to mention that the voiceovers for the replica soldiers is equally as disconcerting.  They talk like normal people.   They are not normal people.  As we learned in F.E.A.R. 2 these Replica soldiers under their masks are facially disfigured cheap human clones with little education or vocal skill, and their voice should be gruffy, low and borderline animalistic.  In F.E.A.R. 3 they talk like professional sports announcers at the International Table Tennis Tournament. When you shoot them, you get a yellow hit marker, and if you squint really hard you might see a tinge of red blood. Where is the gore?  But within 10 minutes you'll also be able to figure out that the introduction of Alma in this game is about as frightening as an angry poodle. Another opportunity wasted.  The use of music in the game is done poorly, and the music itself is completely uninspiring.  Another opportunity wasted. Go into settings.  That's right, auto-aim is on by default, because this is a console port.  All this culminates into F.E.A.R. 3 being a total let down and downright disgrace to what is otherwise a legendary franchise loved by many. When will game publishers learn to stop destroying great concepts in the name of wider market audiences and temporary profit gains?  WB clearly took a page from the EA and Activision book on F.E.A.R. 3 and it's no surprise we'll never see another real F.E.A.R. game again...

content:
, 2014
												I've played FEAR 1 & 2, lots of other horror games and here's what I have to say about FEAR 3....a letdown!  In a nutshell FEAR 3 feels like Call of Duty with a ghost that appears every so often.  FEAR 1 & 2 had major moments of scares and making you feel like you were always haunted.  FEAR 3 is just bad guys, bad guys and more bad guys...then Alma shows up and is gone.  I acknowledge that FEAR 3 is a shooter game but I think it concentrates too much on shooting and not the horror.  Furthermore, I'm upset that you can shoot an enemy in the face a couple of times then he gets back up and shoots and granades you a dozen times.  The AI is a bit too smart as well.  Before you round the corner they're already shooting at you!  Forget ducking for cover because they seem to have an unlimited supply of granades.  By the time I reached a "ghost moment" I was so frustrated that I was basically like, whatever Alma just get outta my way go haunt someone who cares!  The creepy moments are very brief and and they're ok but far from great.  If you like horror games stay away from this, it'll be a letdown.Pros:+Controls (after changing them from default)+Ablility to use cover during a firefight+WeaponsCons:-Graphics (worse than FEAR 2 for some reason)-Enemies keep spawning in some places-Enemies hard to kill even at point blank-No real scary moments, not a true horror game-For a shooter/horror game it's boring.

												Having finished Fear 2, I was wanting more. That game had its issues, but its atmosphere carried it, and it was a great experience overall.Since I had Fear 3, I decidede to give it a try. Well, having finished one playthrough in Fearless difficulty, I can see I was a bit disappointed. BUT, it's not a bad game. Not a bad game at all... just not a very good Fear, in my opinion.This game feels a lot like a modern shooter, without the creepy atmosphere. Besides, there really isn't a very coherent place in which you play. Each level is a different location. While that does provide variety, it doesn't feel very good to just jump from place to place just because. It makes it feel more like an amusement park... Besides, these places don't feel scary anymore. You're not as much is hostile territory anymore, and that was the biggest disappointment.Atmosphere has gone down the drain. For some reason, for the developers, blood everywhere=horror. All there is to it is bloody patterns everywhere, and red candles. These are in almost every level and don't really make much sense. Aside from these candles and blood, there is trash everywhere... even places that make no sense for it to be there. I... I don't know why they'd do this. They went more for the visual component of the environment rather than creating a good, dark atmosphere. It feels very artificial in Fear 3.The supermarket level has some cool places, I'll give them that. And the last level was enjoyable as well. Other than that... meh.The shooting feels better. I'd say gunplay has been improved, and it feels great to shoot human enemies and watch them fall apart. Weapon variety is essentially the same has in the previous game, without alternate firing modes.The new regenerating Health System is a big, big disappointment. Why did they do it? One of the best things in the previous game was exploring for health and armour, and feeling cautious when you had none. This time around, there's no point. If you're low on health, just hide behind cover for a couple of seconds. Another aspect which feels like a modern shooter rather than a Fear game.The mech control was also pretty good.Enemy variety is questionable, and just boils down to a completely average shooter with 2 or 3 additional mini-boss style enemies.Difficulty was fairly easy, with the exception of a couple of completely spikes. Nothing impossible, just pay attention to the environment and choose where to stand/hide and you'll be fine. It's just a shame that it was a bit incoherent in this aspect. Nothing too bad.Visually, it's significantly better than the previous game. Despite being a pretty poor port, that was patched and problem should be solved without too much of an issue. The textures were very blurry, but it wasn't too noticeable unless you were actively looking at them. Lighting effects were really good, I'll give them that. They've used the shadows to enhance atmosphere a bit but it was definitely not enough to carry it. Still, credits where its due, good job on the lighting effects.Animation quality was spot on as well, I'd say, as were the cutscenes. Particle effects were dubious at times, but there were pretty good overall.The music was another aspect that pushed the atmosphere down. Most of the music was very action oriented, taking Fear out of the game. Sound effects weren't nothing to write home about, but nothing too bad. They did the job. Except for Alma's screams. Those were pretty bad, in my opinion.There was no horror in this game, unfortunately. All the scares were jumpscares. And they weren't all that scary, really. Some were good, most were barely noticeable. It's a real shame. They've completely ruined the atmosphere of the game. They've opted for the easy way out, making a modern shooter instead of a Fear game. Environment was based around blood everywhere. Just... blood and symbols. It didn't really feel hostile towards you, and that might be the reason why it didn't feel scary at all.Story was pretty straightforward. Alma's in pregnant (play the last game) and her other 2 sons go after her to do something about it. ♥♥♥♥ happens on the way and half of the city is destroyed. Nothing spectacular, although I did like the ending. Still, nothing that'll get you thinking. It's just an excuse to shoot everything.Collectibles and Achievements... Argh, these were awful. Really awful. Collectibles do absolutely nothing for the player. Except for achievements. But... well, why would one do it? In the last game, you would explore for Intel, which gave you insight on the backstory. This time, there's nothing. Absolutely nothing, and I hate it. They've dumbed down everything that made Fear, Fear! You collect stuff for the sake of it. No context, no reward.Absolutely pointless, and it makes me mad.Besides, there are "challenges" in each level, which simply pushes the player towards a playstyle that isn't necessarily the most fun. It's just about getting x kills with each weapon, hide behind cover for x time, etc. etc.It's not there to improve gameplay in any way, so it might has well not be there, to be honest. Overall impressions. This was a pretty negative review, I realize it. But it's not a bad game. The gameplay feels good, it looks and sounds good... but it has barely anything to do with Fear. It's just another shooter now... maybe a bit more gory, but that's it.And that's definitely not what I was looking for.So, if you're looking for a brainless shooter, go ahead and play this.If you're looking for a well crafted game, with a great atmosphere... look somewhere else.It's a good game. Just not a good Fear game.
